cards.front: How do impedances combine in series?
cards.back: They add directly: Z_eq = Z₁ + Z₂ + ... + Z_N. Identical to resistors in series.

cards.front: How do impedances combine in parallel?
cards.back: Their reciprocals add: 1/Z_eq = 1/Z₁ + 1/Z₂ + ... Or admittances add: Y_eq = Y₁ + Y₂ + ...

cards.front: State the impedance voltage divider formula.
cards.back: V₂ = Z₂/(Z₁+Z₂) × V_s. Identical to the DC voltage divider with impedances replacing resistances.

cards.front: Does KVL work in the phasor domain?
cards.back: Yes! The sum of phasor voltages around any closed loop is zero: ΣV_k = 0. This follows from the additive property of phasors.

cards.front: State the product-over-sum formula for two parallel impedances.
cards.back: Z_eq = Z₁Z₂/(Z₁ + Z₂). Use this when exactly two impedances are in parallel.

cards.front: What is the resonant frequency of a series RLC circuit?
cards.back: ω₀ = 1/√(LC). At this frequency, ωL = 1/(ωC), so the imaginary parts cancel and Z = R (purely real).

cards.front: In a balanced Y-Δ transform, how are Z_Y and Z_Δ related?
cards.back: Z_Y = Z_Δ/3. Each wye impedance is one-third of each delta impedance.

cards.front: What happens at parallel resonance (L and C in parallel at ω₀)?
cards.back: Z_eq → ∞ (open circuit). The parallel LC combination has infinite impedance at the resonant frequency, blocking current flow.

cards.front: Why does admittance simplify parallel circuit analysis?
cards.back: Admittances add directly in parallel (Y_eq = Y₁ + Y₂), avoiding the reciprocal formula. This mirrors how conductances add for parallel DC resistors.

cards.front: Can you use Thevenin/Norton equivalents in the phasor domain?
cards.back: Yes! All DC analysis techniques work in the phasor domain with complex impedances. V_th and Z_th become complex-valued phasor quantities.
